section.title: Purpose
section.para: There is an increasing need for high-quality and accurate data as healthcare organizations becoming more reliant on electronic health records (EHRs), laboratory information systems (LISs), and other electronic information systems. A primary tool for many organizations, terminology standards work to improve the quality and accuracy of data. Terminology standards aim to ensure information is captured and represented in a repeatable and standardized format so that other organizations have a common understanding of the data. While terminology standards are a useful tool, extensive knowledge management (KM) is needed to identify, manage, and share the standardized data that these systems and standards capture. As data flows within and between healthcare systems, the use of different terminology standards, KM processes, and systems themselves can pose a threat to the integrity of data. A recent study found that only 22-68% of data integrity is maintained in a single trip, posing challenges around interpretation, and resulting accuracy around patient care [1].

Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) is an approach to data management that aims to maintain the meaning, integrity, and quality of data as it travels within and between healthcare systems. IKM is an evolving approach to manage disparate terminology standards using a common, centralized, and repeatable representation of data. The use of a common model supports the interoperability of data between disparate terminology standards, well documented version control even when different terminology standards employ their own versioning practices, and the incorporation of new or emerging terminology standards. IKM will use an iterative approach to build upon previous work on Resource Description Frameworks (RDFs) and property graphs with novel ideas and concepts. There is no reference or best practice guide for how an IKM solution can or should operate and will therefore require extensive research, prototyping, and development.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) created a Global Substance Registration System (GSRS) to facilitate the efficient and accurate information exchange on substances within regulated products. The creation of the GSRS knowledge base allowed for standardized, scientific descriptions of substances across regulatory lines, such as within and between countries. The collection and dependencies of knowledge within GSRS presents a direct use case in which IKM and its capabilities can improve GSRS.

section.title: Aims
section.para: The aims of this document serve as a collection of landscape analyses of the GSRS system and its parts within the domains of Integrated Knowledge Management: Knowledge Management, and Knowledge Representation.

section.title: Global Substance Registration System (GSRS)/Unique Ingredient Identifier (UNII) Demonstrations
Knowledge Management: GSRS/UNII Demonstration Project Progress Report [Task 1.3.2]
Temporal Change Assessment of GSRS
section.para: GSRS is a comprehensive system designed to manage and track information about substances, particularly in the context of regulatory compliance and safety. It ensures that updates and modifications to its data are accurately managed and recorded through several key mechanisms.

GSRS employs a simple version control system to keep track of changes to its data. With the use of its unique identifier, any modifications to the record result in the creation of a new version. This allows users to track the history of changes made to a substance, compare different versions of a substance record and revert to previous versions, if necessary [2].

An audit trail is maintained for each substance record, documenting every change made to the data. This includes the nature of the change (e.g., addition, deletion, modification), the date and time of the change, the user or system that made the change, and the specific fields that were altered. Audit trails ensure transparency and accountability, making it possible to review the history of a substance and understand the context of each change [3].

GSRS incorporates data validation and quality control processes to ensure that updates are accurate and consistent. These processes include automated validation checks that verify the integrity and correctness of the data before it is saved, and manual review and approval workflows where changes must be reviewed and approved by authorized personnel before they are finalized [4].

GSRS uses role-based access control (RBAC) to manage who can view and modify substance data. Different roles (e.g., data entry, reviewer, administrator) have different levels of access and permissions. This helps prevent unauthorized changes and ensures that only qualified personnel can make updates [5].

Older versions of substance records and audit logs are archived to ensure that the system remains efficient and performant. Archived data can be retrieved if needed, providing a complete historical record without cluttering the active database [6].

GSRS can integrate with other regulatory and data management systems with the use of its Application Programming Interface (API), ensuring that updates made in GSRS are propagated to other systems as needed [7]. This integration helps maintain consistency across different platforms and reduces the risk of discrepancies.

GSRS provides reporting and analytics capabilities via its API that allow users to generate reports on changes made to substance data [7]. These reports can be used for regulatory submissions, internal audits, and other purposes. Analytics tools can also help identify trends and patterns in the data, supporting better decision-making.

IKM can significantly enhance GSRS by providing a structured framework for capturing, storing, and managing data changes. By creating a centralized repository, IKM ensures that all modifications to substance records are consistently documented, including metadata, such as the date, time, user, and rationale for each change. This facilitates robust version control, allowing users to track, compare, and revert to different versions of records as needed. Additionally, IKM enhances audit trails by providing detailed records of all actions taken on substance data, supporting regulatory compliance, and internal audits. Improved data validation and quality control processes, along with enhanced reporting and analytics capabilities, enable GSRS to maintain data integrity and gain insights into data change patterns. Overall, IKM promotes transparency, accountability, and collaboration among stakeholders, ensuring that data changes are accurately tracked and managed over time.

section.title: GSRS Release Process
section.para: The FDA's Global Substance Registration System (GSRS) releases new versions of data by updating its public database with new substance information, typically through a scheduled update process, and makes the updated data accessible via its online platform, allowing users to search and download the latest information using unique ingredient identifiers (UNIIs) as the primary access point. New versions are often accompanied by version numbers and release dates to indicate changes made to the dataset [8].

The release process for new data versions in the Global Substance Registration System (GSRS) is a meticulously structured procedure designed to ensure the integrity, accuracy, and compliance of substance information. This process begins with the identification and documentation of necessary updates or modifications to existing substance records. These changes can stem from new regulatory requirements, scientific discoveries, or corrections to previously entered data. Once the need for an update is identified, the proposed changes undergo an initial review by subject matter experts who assess the validity and implications of the modifications.

Following the initial review, the changes are entered into a staging environment within the GSRS, where they are subjected to automated validation checks. These checks verify the integrity and correctness of the data, ensuring that it adheres to predefined standards and formats. If the data passes these automated checks, it moves on to a manual review process. During this phase, authorized personnel, typically comprising senior data managers or regulatory experts, meticulously examine the changes. They ensure that the updates are not only accurate but also compliant with relevant regulatory guidelines and standards [7].

GSRS utilizes its public website as the primary communication platform to inform users about new updates and developments. The website is regularly updated with the latest information, including new substance registrations, regulatory changes, and enhancements to the system. Users can access detailed announcements, release notes, and documentation that provide insights into the updates. Additionally, the GSRS website may feature newsletters, alerts, and other resources to ensure that users are well-informed and can seamlessly integrate the latest changes into their workflows. This proactive approach helps maintain transparency and keeps stakeholders engaged with the ongoing improvements in the system [9].

The final step in the release process involves the actual deployment of the new data version into the live GSRS environment. This deployment is carefully monitored to ensure it proceeds smoothly and that the system remains functional and efficient. Post-release, the system maintains an audit trail documenting every change made to the data, including the nature of the change, the date and time, the user or system that made the change, and the specific fields that were altered. This audit trail ensures transparency and accountability, making it possible to review the history of a substance and understand the context of each change [10].

An opportunity for GSRS seems to be enhancing its version control system, which currently relies on the use of its unique identifier system. IKM can help GSRS with versioning and the release of new data versions by providing a centralized platform for managing and tracking changes. IKM ensures that all updates and modifications are documented and version-controlled, allowing for clear visibility of changes over time. It facilitates the creation and maintenance of release notes and documentation for each new data version, ensuring that all stakeholders are informed of updates. Additionally, IKM supports the coordination and communication among team members, streamlining the release process and ensuring that new data versions are deployed efficiently and accurately.

To elaborate more on IKM’s versioning capabilities, it facilitates the systematic tracking of data changes, ensuring that every modification is documented with detailed metadata, including timestamps, user information, and change descriptions. This meticulous version control allows for precise auditing and rollback capabilities, ensuring data integrity and consistency. By implementing IKM, GSRS can maintain a comprehensive history of all data entries and updates, which is crucial for regulatory compliance and accurate substance registration. Furthermore, IKM supports collaboration among multiple users by preventing data conflicts and ensuring that the most current and accurate information is always available. This leads to enhanced data reliability, streamlined workflows, and improved decision-making processes within the GSRS framework.

section.title: Conclusion
section.para: The GSRS system is a robust and comprehensive platform for substance registration and management. Its open-source nature, combined with community contributions and adherence to international standards, makes it a valuable tool for the pharmaceutical and chemical industries. The system's functionalities, user-friendly interface, and compliance support are key strengths that enhance its utility and effectiveness.
To further improve the GSRS system, the following recommendations are proposed:

listitem.para: Enhance User Training: Provide additional training resources and support to help users maximize the system's capabilities.
Increase Community Engagement: Encourage greater participation from the community to drive innovation and continuous improvement.
Strengthen Data Security: Implement advanced security measures to protect sensitive substance data and ensure compliance with data protection regulations.
Integrate Advanced Analytics: Incorporate advanced analytics tools to provide deeper insights into substance data and support decision-making processes.
Expand Data Model: Conduct additional analysis to understand how database can be expanded by integrating into other knowledge standards.
Utilize Validation Tools: Integrate automated validation tools where possible to assist with routine checks, reducing the burden on manual processes and minimizing human error.

Implement More Robust Version Tracking: Integrate an IKM system that helps track and log every change made to substance data, including detailed metadata such as user information, timestamps, and change descriptions to enhance data integrity, facilitate auditing, and ensure accurate version control.

section.para: By implementing these recommendations, GSRS can continue to evolve and meet the growing needs of the pharmaceutical and chemical industries, ensuring accurate and reliable substance registration and management.

section.title: Knowledge Representation: GSRS/UNII Demonstration Project Progress Report [Task 3.3.1]
Introduction
section.para: Following the completion of the initial investigation and the designation of data elements that can be represented by existing Tinkar components, we continued with our representation of GSRS by establishing the additional data used, authoring this starter data in Komet, and creating transformation logic to be used to generate the data set. Our focus has been on expanding the Tinkar framework to accommodate new patterns for data elements that could not be represented by existing concepts. These enhancements are designed to provide a more comprehensive and accurate representation of GSRS data and is part of our broader IKM strategy, which aims to facilitate seamless data sharing and collaboration across different regulatory and scientific databases.

section.title: Modeling GSRS
section.para: Out of the 23 data elements, GSRS includes five key data elements that are consistently present: UNII, Display Name, Ingredient Type, Substance Type, and Universally Unique Identifier (UUID). UNII, Display Name, Substance Type, and UUID can be represented using existing Tinkar concepts, as highlighted in Table 1. However, Ingredient Type could not be represented using an existing Tinkar concept, so a new pattern was created for Ingredient Type.

The team also created new patterns for Molecular Formula (MF) and Simplified Molecular-Input Line-Entry System (SMILES). MF is the chemical formula that lists all the elements, plus how many atoms of each element, are present in a chemical compound [11]. It specifies the chemical proportions of the atoms within a particular GSRS substance ingredient. The MF describes useful information on the substance and is beneficial in ensuring accurate data. SMILES stands for the Simplified Molecular-Input Line-Entry System and represents the structure of a molecule using a simple string of characters [12]. It translates the MF into a text format that is easier to understand and manipulate. Each substances corresponding SMILES is useful in verifying consistency in the data.

The team included an identifier for RxCUI. RxCUI stands for RxNorm Concept Unique Identifier and is a unique numeric code that identifies a drug entity in RxNorm [13]. RxNorm is a data standard that includes normalized names for clinical drugs. RxCUIs are used to support the semantic interoperation between drug terminologies and various pharmacy knowledge base systems like GSRS. Since RxNorm is also part of our greater IKM, RxCUI is a GSRS element that supports the integration of drug and ingredient information and facilitates interoperability across different systems.

These eight elements serve as the first representation of GSRS. Table 1 details how this starter set was modeled.
Table 1: GSRS Modeled Starter Data
Description Semantics
Display Name
Preferred Term - Preferred Substance Name - Display Name
FQN - Use the Official Name
Identifier Semantics
UNII
FQN – Unique Ingredient Identifier
UUID
FQN – Global Substance Registration System Universal Unique Identifier
RxCUI
FQN – RxNorm Concept Unique Identifier
Stated Definition Semantics
Substance_Type – for substances with NO RxCUI ID
The ISO 11238 substance type used for the primary substance identity including:
chemicals, nucleic acids, proteins, polymers, structurally diverse, mixtures and concepts (SpecifiedSubstanceG1).
All substances will have at least a “simple” stated definition of what substance they are.
Substance_Type – for substances with a RxCUI ID
The substances that have an RXCUI ID will have a more hierarchical logical definition if RxNorm and SNOMED have been loaded and the reasoner has been run. The RXCUI ID will link to RxNorm to then link to a SNOMED CT concept code. The corresponding SNOMED CT concept code will provide a hierarchical logical definition.
New Patterns
Molecular Formula (MF)
Semantic Purpose:
Molecular Formula Semantic
Semantic Meaning
Molecular Formula Semantic
Field 1:
Meaning: Molecular Formula
Purpose: Molecular Formula
Field Type: String
SMILES
Semantic Purpose:
SMILES Semantic
Semantic Meaning
SMILES Semantic
Field 1:
Meaning: SMILES
Purpose: SMILES
Field Type: String
Ingredient_Type – UNII grouping based on intended role: Ionic Moiety, Ingredient Substance, Molecular Fragment, Specified Substance, Unspecified Ingredient.
Semantic Purpose:
Ingredient Type Semantic
Semantic Meaning
Ingredient Type Semantic
Field 1:
Meaning: Ingredient Type
Purpose: Ingredient Type
Field Type: Component Field
New Concepts for:
Ionic Moiety
Molecular Fragment
Ingredient Substance
Specified Substance
Unspecific Ingredient

The remaining 15 data elements were not included in the GSRS starter data as analysis concluded they are not essential for ensuring consistency, accuracy, and interoperability across various systems. While the team was focused on creating a starter set that encompassed the major areas of GSRS that form the foundation of the shared knowledge base, these elements could be included as Identifier Semantics in the future to build off the pre-existing relationships. Table 2 highlights these elements and why they were not included for this starter set. Table 2: GSRS Data That Is Not Included
Data Element Why this element was not included
EC
European Chemicals Agency registry number (formerly known EINECS)
This identifier is specific to chemical substances registered in Europe and may not be relevant for datasets focusing on broader or different geographical regions.
NCIT
NCI Thesaurus Concept Code
This code is specific to the National Cancer Institute's thesaurus, which might be too specialized for datasets not focused on cancer research or related fields.
RN
Registry Number used by many public chemical information systems particularly CAS Common Chemistry
While useful for chemical databases, this number might be too specific for general datasets that do not require detailed chemical information.
PUBCHEM
PubChem Compound ID
This ID is specific to the PubChem database, which may not be necessary for datasets that do not require detailed chemical compound information.
INCHIKEY
A fixed-length string created from the IUPAC International Chemical Identifier (InChI)
This identifier is highly specific to chemical informatics and may not be relevant for datasets that do not require precise chemical structure information.
EPA_CompTox
EPA Substance ID
This ID is specific to the Environmental Protection Agency's CompTox database, which might be too specialized for datasets not focused on environmental toxicology.
CATALOGUE_OF_LIFE
Catalogue of Life organism ID
This identifier is specific to biological taxonomy and may not be relevant for datasets that do not focus on biodiversity or taxonomic classification
ITIS
Integrated Taxonomic Information System Taxonomic Serial Number (ITIS TSN)
Similar to the Catalogue of Life ID, this is specific to taxonomic classification and may not be necessary for datasets not focused on biological taxonomy.
NCBI
NCBI taxonomy organism ID
This ID is specific to the National Center for Biotechnology Information's taxonomy database and may be too specialized for datasets not focused on genetic or biological research.
PLANTS
USDA PLANTS organism ID
This identifier is specific to the USDA PLANTS database and may not be relevant for datasets that do not focus on plant taxonomy or agriculture.
GRIN
USDA Agricultural Research Service Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) nomen ID
This ID is specific to the GRIN database and may be too specialized for datasets not focused on agricultural research or germplasm resources.
MPNS
Kew Gardens Medicinal Plants Name Service Record ID (includes source database prefix)
This identifier is specific to medicinal plants and may not be relevant for datasets that do not focus on medicinal botany or pharmacognosy.
INN_ID
Sequential number assigned by World Health Organization's International Nonproprietary Name (INN) Programme
This ID is specific to the WHO's INN Programme and may be too specialized for datasets not focused on pharmaceutical substances.
USAN_ID
Alphanumeric code used by American Medical Association’s United States Adopted Names (USAN) Council
This identifier is specific to the USAN Council and may not be relevant for datasets that do not focus on pharmaceutical naming conventions.
DAILYMED
UNIIs known to be associated with regulated product listings on DailyMed
This ID is specific to the DailyMed database and may be too specialized for datasets not focused on regulated pharmaceutical products.

There are types of names that are not included in this starter set, but can be included in the future. Systematic Name (sys), Common Name (cn), Code (cd), and Brand/Trade Name (bn) can be added as identifier semantics.

section.title: GSRS Transformation Logic
section.para: The transformation logic is used to create Java code that uses raw data from GSRS to generate its corresponding Tinkar representation.

First, the user will select the UNII data they need from https://precision.fda.gov/uniisearch/archive and download the file. They will unzip the file and open UNII_Records_DATE in excel. As shown in Table 3, The STAMP coordinate for GSRS is based on the UNII data file used. Table 3: GSRS STAMP Coordinates
Status Time Author Module Path
Active
Date of File
EX: the file UNII_Data_20241220 has a Time value of 2024-12-20
GSRS Author Concept GSRS Module Concept Master Path

Status defaults to active because the component is in use. Time is based on the date written in the name of the UNII data file that was previously downloaded. Author is GSRS Author Concept because it represents the author responsible for authoring the change. Module is GSRS Module Concept because it is an assignment based on the corresponding terminology. Path is Master Path because it is currently the default branch for components.

The user will begin by creating a new concept with the Name space and its corresponding UNII. This single concept will have three different UUIDs: UNII, RxCUI UUID, and FDA UUID. If RxCUI is not present, then the concept will not get that value and will have only a UNII and an FDA UUID. Every semantic that gets created has its own UUID. The description semantic that is created will have a reference component to the above UNII and follow the description pattern. The Language field will be the [English Language] concept. The Description Text value will be the literal string provided in the display name column. The Case Specificity field would be the [Case Insensitive] concept because the case sensitivity does not matter. The Description Type would be the [Fully Qualified Name].

Next, the user will create three semantics of the identifier pattern for UNII, RxCUI, and FDA UUID. Beginning with UNII, the Identifier Source will be UNII, and the Identifier Value will be the literal string provided in the UNII column. For RxCUI, the Identifier Source will be RxCUI, and the Identifier Value will be the literal string provided in the RxCUI column. For FDA UUID, the Identifier Source will be FDA UUID and the Identifier Value will be the literal string provided in the UUID column.

Then, the user will create a new semantics of the three patterns previously discussed. Beginning with Molecular Formula, Field 1 will be the literal string provided in the MF column. For SMILES, Field 1 will be the literal string provided in the SMILES column. For Ingredient Type, Field 1 is a Component Field of the five starter data ingredient types that have been created: Ionic Moiety, Molecular Fragment, Ingredient Substance, Specified Substance, and Unspecific Ingredient.

Finally, the user will create a new axiom semantic for Substance Type. The Substance Type concept is a subclass of UNII. The substance types are Chemicals, Concepts, Mixtures, Nucleic Acids, Polymers, Proteins, and Structurally diverse and are all starter data concepts that have been created.

section.title: Summary of Findings
section.para: This deliverable builds upon the initial progress report by further detailing the modeling and representation of the GSRS data elements in the context of IKM and its respective domains. The creation of new patterns has expanded the capability of Tinkar to accurately represent the complex data inherent in GSRS. Additionally, the inclusion of RxCUI identifiers enhances the interoperability of GSRS with other drug and ingredient information systems, facilitating seamless data integration and consistency. The outlined transformation logic provides a clear and systematic approach for converting raw GSRS data into its corresponding Tinkar representation, ensuring that the data is accurately and efficiently processed. This logic not only supports the initial data elements but also lays the groundwork for future expansions to include additional identifiers and semantic patterns.

section.title: Next Steps
section.para: As we move forward, the focus will be on refining these models, addressing any gaps found in the current representation, and exploring the inclusion of the remaining data elements as needed. By continuing to build on this foundation, we aim to enhance the quality, consistency, and interoperability of GSRS data, ultimately contributing to more robust and integrated knowledge management systems. The progress made thus far demonstrates the potential for substantial improvements in data quality and accessibility in healthcare, setting the stage for continued advancements in the field.

section.title: Conclusion
section.para: This deliverable serves as the initial progress report of the GSRS system in the context of IKM and its respective domains. This document details the two arenas in which IKM expertise can improve areas of concern within GSRS. Our summary of findings identifies areas of focus to be addressed in subsequent reports and will require additional and continued efforts to improve the implementation, functionality, and adoption of IKM solutions into GSRS. GSRS serves as just one area of opportunity in which IKM can make substantive improvements to its systems and result in better quality of data.
